caption: In support of my department and team, I create and refine documentation of our UX process to point to for direction and for others to reference as needed.
I created and refined the onboarding processes for my UX department to get all new team members up to speed quickly and equally.
My team and I created training videos to demonstrate and train others on our style guide-driven development process.
I developed a hiring workflow for recruiting new UX team members and leveraged this workflow to help clients like Yum! Brands to build their UX team.
New hires don't come from the same backgrounds and bring the same skillsets. I developed an assessment to level set with all new hires, identifying gaps and establishing a training plan.
I create a UX project plan for all new projects to communicate and capture stakeholder buy-in for how we will approach the work.
Leveraging existing resources for UI design, I developed a UX checklist to capture information in the pre-sales, contract, and kickoff phases.
I have found it beneficial to create and share templates with team members to have a starting point for user testing & observations,  presentations, and workshops.
I think that it is essential to start every project organized. A table of contents allows tracking and sharing of information in a single, bookmarkable location.
Here you see an example of a design review for a client project produced and delivered as a video.
Research comes in all shapes and sizes, but it typically starts as sketches and annotations to visualize and communicate thoughts, concepts, and direction.
I have found it beneficial to create and share templates with team members to have a starting point for user testing & observations,  presentations, and workshops.
Creating personas to represent your user helps communicate with stakeholders and the team details of the intended audience.
I believe in 'ugly first' - focus on layout and functionality first. This is the time to ideate, fail, problem solve, and iterate.
Once you have a solid sketch concept in place, it is time to create quick, simple digital wireframes to use to build testable prototypes.
I like to create video mockups to communicate to the stakeholder and my developers the product's vision.
Mockups increase from low to high fidelity the more you prove the interaction design is solid. Leveraging a design system helps to expedite this process.

I prefer to create prototypes using Axure. Axure is a powerful tool that allows for the simulation of input fields, leverages actual product data, and provides the user an experience more similar to the final environment.
Paper prototyping speeds up the time to get a concept in front of users.
Recording user tests is an excellent way to capture feedback while focusing on the user. I will create highlight clips from the recordings to share and communicate with stakeholders.
